climbs.name: White Eye
climbs.fa: Michael Layton and James Garrett, Fall 2008

content.description:
P1: Paddle up the low angle slab passing 3 bolts at various cruxes. The climbing is extremely easy but very loose in spots and with minimal protection. A two bolt anchor with tat awaits.

P2: Walk up to the rib with bolts then edge and smear your way up past the 5.8 crux. The climbing eases off to a two bolt anchor.

P3: Wander right up a runnel before cutting back left onto the slab. Pass a lone bolt before running into the two bolt anchor. No chains there as of 11/15 so bring some tat and rings or a couple leaver biners.
content.protection: Quickdraws were sufficient. It's very runout but the climbing in between the difficult sections is so absurdly easy it would be a waste of time to place gear. No more than 4 quickdraws are needed for any pitch.
content.location:
Look on the right side of the southern face of the main formation. The route starts on the lowest part of the formation just left of a major gully system. A couple shiny bolts help you find the start.

Rap off the top with a 70M rope or walk off to the east and then back south.

content.description: Cruise straight up the edges. Watch out for loose rock. No idea who the FA is or name of route. Please comment if you have more info.
content.protection: 4 bolts or so to a pair of bolts with no chains. I left some biners on the bolts to aid in toproping but the routes could use some tat and rings or chains.
content.location: Just to the right of the 5.6. On the southeast side of the main rock formation.

content.description: Cruise straight up the edges. Watch out for loose rock. No idea who the FA is or name of route. Please comment if you have more info.
content.protection: About 4 bolts to the shared chains with the 5.7 to the right.
content.location: Look about 100 feet right and uphill of White Eye across the toe of the gully. This route and the 5.7 are easily visible from the parking area.

content.description: Three bolts traverse the lower huecos, then transitions to face climbing. A TR fall could be dangerous, with a swing into the big boulder at the base. (We did not try this one, so I have no idea if it is 11, 12, or 13, but I don't want to confuse anyone with the 5 climbs up here.)
content.location: Up the Three Dames gulley, the rightmost of the three on the left. You could set a TR by scampering around to the top.

content.description: Neat hueco start, to some delicate face, to some very thin face.
content.location: Up the Three Dames gulley, farthest climb to the left. You could set a TR by scampering around to the top.

content.description:
Very thin, slightly dihedral, through a slight black streak...

(We did not try this one, so I have no idea if it is 11, 12, or 13, but I don't want to confuse anyone with the 5 climbs up here.)
content.location: Up the Three Dames gulley, farthest climb to the far right. For now, you have to set a TR from the top, either by scampering or coming around from the climb to the left.

content.description: Really fun overhanging start, very tricky traverse to gain the ledge, and a cruiser to the top
content.location: Up the Three Dames gulley, go to the right to the really pretty heucos down low. You could set a TR by scampering around to the top.

content.description: Hard hueco start, very hard getting to the face, eventually even harder getting through some sloper huecos.
content.location: Up the Three Dames gulley, middle of the three climbs on the left. You could set a TR by scampering around to the top.

content.description:
This route starts roughly 30 feet to the right of the obvious water mark that is Dumpster Diver.  Start on an easy, runout, bolted line that slightly travels left from the base.  Pull through crumbly rock until you see a two bolt anchor on the left roughly three bolts up.  This is the belay ledge for the second pitch.  The second pitch travels up the water mark, featuring chossy climbing up easy terrain.  The last bolt is before an INCREDIBLY DANGEROUS chimney section which runs out to the anchors.  Use extreme caution on this section - it really needs to be cleaned up and the belayers will be avoiding flying rocks otherwise.  The second pitch is roughly 130', so rappelling off with a 70M rope is ill-advised.  Try rap'ing with the Dumpster Diver anchors or possibly avoid this adventure climb altogether until it gets safer.  PG13 for runout and falling rocks from rope drag and climbers.

As a side note, you can continue up bolts from the the belay ledge up an unknown route.  I went three bolts past the belay ledge and called it quits after being unable to find the next bolt on crumbly rock without beta.  Kudos to the intrepid climber who can send this unknown, yet easy route.
content.protection: Bolts.  1st pitch - 4 bolts + anchors (incredibly run out) 2nd pitch - around 6 bolts + anchors (also incredibly run out)

content.description: Crux is at the beginning of the third, final, and best pitch. Bolt finding skills will be tested! Treat yo-self to this adventure climb. Excellent views from the top. Rap off at your own leisure, or down climb a rib on east, southeast side.
content.location: Head to the south face. There are two trees at the base of the cliff. Follow a faint game trail just in front of the east most tree. Look up thirty feet for your first bolt. Between H-Unknown and I-White Eye from the Beta Photo.

climbs.name: Feels Like Africa
climbs.fa: James Garrett and Franziska Garrett, 25 Oct 2019

content.description:
The crux is up high on this short crimpy climb on water worn black streaked granite.

Pitch#1: Just to the right of Unknown aka White Spot, look for a line of Wave Glue In bolts. Two steep steps with a lower angle easier section in the middle to a two bolt belay. 5.10, 6 bolts.

Rappel the Route.
content.protection: QDs for Glue In Bolts. Well protected.
content.location: Walk to the White Spot area and bear right (East) toward a cave like feature with an unknown older bolted route on the left of the wall and this in the Middle.

climbs.name: Earth Angel
climbs.fa: Troy Anderson, Tyler Phillips and families 2010

content.description:
This slab route has an old school taste with good protection. Drilled from the ground up. Probably the best longer moderate route out here.

P1- Pad up to the first bolt and keep padding upwards passing bolts, one which you wont forget. The crumbly shoulder to the belay is memorable.

P2- Climb straight  up passing two clips to a big shelf. Stop here and belay at two bolts or link into P3.

P3- Jog left and around the corner to Atomic Sheep and belay. Or ramble up the low angle terrrain passing a bolt or tow to the top. This has the best belay ledge on the whole dome IMO.
content.protection: Mostly bolts. A few shoulder length runners are nice. Cams to #2 if headed towards Atomic Sheep
content.location: Located just  to the left of the Three Dame Crack.

content.description:
This is a fun route up a water streak on the south side of Moon Rock. Lots of features, pockets and a generally low angle keep this on the easier side for the majority of the route.

P1 - Pull a bulge protected by a bolt and head upwards Big thanks to James Garrett for fixing the damaged hangars!.

P2 - Motor up the streak and veer right when it splits. Clip two more bolts at the top before topping out. Belay off the bolts at the top.
content.protection: A single set of cams will be enough for some leaders though a double set might be a better idea for those who don't like long runouts.
content.location:
The route starts on the south side of Moon Rock. Look for a large obvious black water streak.

Rappel to the east off the anchor for White Eye. One 70m rope will work. 3 rappels or 2 and a short bit of 3/4th class down-climbing.
